_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Nursery, Garden Center, and Farm Supply Stores

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan - EXECUTIVE SUMMARY for Forest Agronomy

1. The Facility Policy

The owners, management, and employees of Midland-Impact, LLP, are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, LEPC, or other agencies, to control any release and to minimize the impact of the release to people, property and the environment.

2. Facility Information

The primary activity at Forest Agronomy is the storage and blending of fertilizers for custom application and sale to farmers.

Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application for crop production nutrients. 

The maximum quantity stored would be 580,000 pounds in our 26,000-gallon and 12,000 gallon storage tanks plus the contents of of a rail tank car (160,000 lbs.)and 56 - 1000 gallon nurse tanks. The maximum quantity handled would be the unloading of  a rail tank car holding 160,000 pounds. Anhydrous ammonia is distributed to farmers in the 1000 gallon nurse trailers.

3. The accident release prevention program
Forest Agronomy has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1", published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc., the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia" and the Office of Indiana State Chemist "Indiana Ammonia Law". 

4. The Five-year Accident History 

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that:- to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, shelter in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

5. The emergency response program

The facility has:

a. A written emergency response plan, in accordance with OSHA standards 29 CFR 1910.38.

b. Provided state and local authorities the emergency pla

nning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA).

c. A written emergency action program, in accordance with OSHA standard  29 CFR 1910.120, including pre-emergency planning and employee training.

6. Planned changes to improve safety

Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility. Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. There are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations for implementation at this time.
